county fair

        in an empty stall

junk car

          beneath the hood

the Christmas 
          after we told them

a bit of rust

               a scapula

that time of year

text.8:
winter solstice
          the tilt

text.9:
first morning

          wander the streets
text.10:
flies wait it out 
          under a cow’s chin

text.11:
heartwood 
          the saw changes 
          its tune
text.12:
snow field 
          the earth marked

text.13:
setting sun 
          an accordion squeezes

text.14:
no moon 
          the click of stilettos

text.15:
flowing estuary 
          native languages 
          long gone
text.16:
in the hot tub 
          my eyes on her floating breasts

text.17:
rosebud unfolding 
          the seed packet left behind 
          in Revelations
text.19:
river mud
          the shape
          of boys
text.21:
desert twilight

text.22:
we huddle
          over mother’s open grave—
          lawless winter
text.23:
a long bus ride
          the prophetic language
          of the stops
text.24:
Navajo moon
          the coyote call

text.25:
deleting words
          from the eulogy
          falling leaves
text.27:
calla lily
          the sound of a ladder
          lengthening
text.28:
tasting the well 
          in the water—
          summer stars
text.29:
Mother’s Day
          the expiration date

text.30:
northern lights . . .
          the scratchy play 
          of seventy-eights
text.31: a recurring escape from my father’s dream
text.32:
the big dipper
          no matter where I stand

text.33:
summer passing
          the yard flamingo’s

text.34:
glint of sunlight:
          the respirator carries on
          alone
text.35:
All Souls Day...

autumn

text.37:
hunter's cabin: 
          of the woods 
          not of it
text.38:
end of the walk

cafe for sale—

day lilies 
          another death date added

text.41:
The house finch

crescent moon

close enough to touch—

text.44:
Blowing leaves
          tempt the old cat,

ancient mountains . . .

Thanksgiving—

blossoms . . . 
          the baby’s bare feet

one moth 
          a thousand candles
          light the darkness

          my pebble

family reunion—

text.52:
a jar of pennies

lightning . . .
          the scarecrow's coat sleeve

          the hammock turned in

season of lights

mallard pair

a bee chose

soba noodles . . .

a stick caught

winter drags on . . .

distant thunder—

          each slice of the cake

          a decade has passed
          by your grave

after the funeral
          whiskers still

the page-finders

first buds of spring

Among the gravestones

text.78:
whalebone
          from a beach near Savoonga—

cremated
          in her favorite kimono—

spring rain—
          the gravedigger latches the door

loon calls

summer evening—
          from across the meadow

shivering on the roof

ocean breeze—

autumn rose—
               even as I sketch the wind

Humid July—
          from the stove the smell

the wind of autumn

broken easel
          the front yard blue

heat waves
          the hitchhiker shifts her child

text.92:
land's end
          sand in each bite

Indian summer
          a fish slips through

her 18th birthday
          for the first time she notices

meteor shower—
              a gentle wave

mountain hike

text.99:
snail—
          to know 
                     its heart beats too

lethal injection
          unable to shut

end of summer

new in town

catalog time

new butterfly . . .

morning overcast

break up

walking home barefoot,
          we enter the shadow

autumn evening

storm clouds

winter beach

riveredge old growth:

I'm caught in it too—

Over the railroad tracks

leaf in my palm 
          its stem extends

text.122:
about the tree 
          over my small son's grave
          —tell me

musty smell

that Venus! 
          leading the cupped moon

the river—
          coming to it with nothing
          in my hands

deep silence

          the long tips of lavender

the dumproad pond

still sun-warmed . . .

winter seclusion

on the path 
          only one of us

winter, bedtime

warm river—
          up to our necks

beneath the ice

after the stroke. . .
          watching only the half of your face

          mountains and pines

          an empty snail shell

snowflakes

bright leaves

on the river 
                of many names, one cloud

learning too late

the war memorial—

falling leaves 
          the house comes

text.152:
leaving you—
          fog on either side 
          of the white heron

Below zero

deep winter.

snowmelt . . .
               she enters

an old woolen sweater

a white horse

sunlight shines red 
          through my father's thumb

two women crying 
          one giving birth 
                    the other being born
text.162:
Approaching the family plot . . .
          my furled umbrella

Chernobyl victim—

cloud shadow

Roses
          in the smaller room

silent cathedral

up the path

dry leaves

soft rain—

morning sneeze—

dusk

so many ways

figure drawing class—

              a little sea

watching rain

abandoned store—

a single strand 
          of spider silk

taking time . . .

in soap bubbles

full moon

dusk

light

such coolness

bird song 
          lost

walking in on her

in the sea 
          the fireworks 
          rising

circling each thigh 
               cool 
          of the night river

small child

in utter stillness

canyon: 
          at the very edge

between the fireflies

text.220:

under trees and sky

migrating geese—

sound of her voice

moving

heart drawn in dust

snowman's eye

ten below zero:

hot wind

the old man

a spider's web

under the back steps

dead mynah bird . . .

and yet 
          perishable is flesh—

the wind 
          somewhere else—

apples cooking:

in a dark bag

still lake—

small town

stick figures

text.329:
As if it were spring 
        the green mold 
        on the cheese
text.330:
psychic fair 
        she brushes some dirt 
        from the cards
text.332:
day moon
        a fresh tattoo rises
        out of her jeans
text.333:
Independence Day
        I struggle to free myself
        from a wet swim suit
text.334:
fresh blueberries
        a 'gothic' teenager
        darkens her lips
text.335:
switchbacks—
        five or six cub scouts
        an octave higher
text.336:
my father and I
        paint the barn
        compare wars
text.337:
picnic
        in the sun-dappled courtyard
        my freckled banana
text.338:
in the dream
        my dog has a whistle
        only I can hear
text.339:
rodeo cowboy
        hopefully clutching
        a handful of sky
text.340:
two-way glass—
        the patient waits inside
        the therapist's reflection
text.341:
rush hour—
        the blonde in the Porsche peels
        an orange
text.342:
scar on her cheek
        she gets her lipstick
        just right
text.343:
grocery shopping—
        his python tattoo
        squeezes the Charmin
text.344:
on display:
        her small and firm
        opinion of men
text.345:
conservatory,
        the carnivorous plants
        behind glass
text.346:
grinding sausage meat
        she recounts the times
        her husband cheated
text.347:
aftershock
        the picture on the wall
        straightens
text.348:
in the middle
        of making love
        counting syllables
text.349:
nudist camp
        where to begin
        with the sunblock
text.350:
Clothesline—
        the shirt shows off
        its biceps
text.351:
open mike night
        the audience
        goes dead
text.352:
getting acquainted
        I learn another name
        for wild radish
text.353:
divorced
        she cleans the ring
        around the tub
text.355:
nest of black hair
        secured with ball-point pens
            office geisha
text.356:
naked at the ironing board
            concentrating
                on a crease
text.358:
freezing wind
        the body builder pumps gas 
        in a muscle shirt
text.359:
werewolf movie 
        at the commercial 
        letting the dog out
text.360:
winter rain 
        holding the umbrella 
        over the dachshundpissing
text.361:
the clerk’s lip ring
        I forget
        what I wanted
text.362:
in the midway sun
        corn on the cob customers
        grinning ear to ear
text.364:
At the fence
        they sit on their tractors
        talking hay
text.365:
three surgeons
        five nurses
        wrong leg
text.366:
Full moon
        I iron a wrinkle
        into his pants
text.367:
Valentine’s Day
        she reminds me
        to fasten my seatbelt
text.368:
before the guests arrive
        I straighten
        the straight cushions
text.369:
a lull in her hands
        the hairstylist asks
        how I part my hair
text.370:
in one room
        everything she has
        and a window
text.371:
Floating
        in the dishwater
        a pair of chopsticks
text.372:
serious
        she takes off her sunglasses
        to speak english
text.373:
nude beach
        an empty bikini
        turns me on
text.374:
dropping valentine chocolates
        he quickly swaps them
        for another box
text.375:
leaning back
        in their chairs
        old friends reunited
text.376:
saving her best dishes
        for a better day
        my eighty year old mother
text.378:
blowing out
        one birthday candle:
        the whole family
text.379:
“Just Married”
        the attendant
        pumping too much gas
text.380:
family reunion
        everywhere I look
        my old nose
text.381:
identical twins
        their hair neatly parted
        on opposite sides
text.382:
at the flea market
        looking through books
        I gave away
text.383:
nightfall
        the zookeeper
        lets himself out
text.384:
tourist town
        postcards of the waterfall
        racked upside down
text.385:
carrying their canes
        two old women lean
        on each other
text.386:
first date
        in the parking lot
        our car doors touch
text.387:
parents coaxing
        baby to eat
        mouths wide open
text.388:
handsome vendor
        my name
        on a grain of rice
text.389:
driving lesson done
        father and daughter run
        fingers through their hair
text.390:
naked
        on the bathroom scales
        stomach held in
text.391:
reconciliation
        the candle between us
        sputters
text.392:
his ashes scattered
        what to do
        with the box
text.393:
nude beach
        his enormous
        sand castle
text.394:
letting the dog out
        letting the dog in
        wrong dog
text.395:
A gusting breeze
        the comet wobbles
        in my binoculars
text.396:
long walk home
        kicking a stone
        for company
text.397:
Christmas Day
        the exchange
        of custody
text.398:
honeymoon trip
        he refuses to stop
        for directions
text.399:
clicking off the late movie . . .
           the couch cushion
               reinflates
text.400:
opening night . . .
        missing the entrance
        of the night blooming cereus
text.401:
Forgetting his underwear
        the one with so many
        frequent flier miles
text.402:
summer concert
        fanning myself faster
        during the scherzo
text.403:
overmatched boxer
        his eyes closed
        before the fight
text.404:
yard sale:
        she takes the baby crib
        back into the house
text.405:
his toe
        answers mine
        a truce begin
text.406:
making sure
        nothing grows
        the rock gardener
text.407:
too quick to reply
        cutting my tongue
        on the envelope
text.408:
Grandfather’s funeral
        Cousin Kate, air kissing,
        Spies a mirror, checks her makeup.
text.409:
in a semi circle
        retired sisters watch
        “Wheel of Fortune”
text.410:
dissatisfied
        with her Virgo horoscope
                       she tries Pisces
text.411:
first time
        at the zoo my son
        watches the people
text.412:
antiquities room
        the curator asks
        “So what’s new?”
text.413:
meeting her boyfriend
                our handshake
                        out of synch
text.414:
from the Holy Land
        he sends a postcard of cracks
        two thousand hears old
text.415:
Polaroid of her lover
        coming clearer
        with time
text.416:
visitor’s day
        buttons just right
        her dress inside out
text.417:
Blueberries
        we show each other
        our tongues
text.418:
battered child
        . . . kicking the swing
        higher
text.419:
a pause in the lecture
        all at once three students
        cross their legs
text.421:
whacking the bat
        with a broom, she says
        they attack people
text.422:
Clear about
        everything
        the window washer
text.423:
dining out
        next to the window
        her coat
text.424:
late spring blossoms
        the silhouette artist facing
                               another ponytail
text.425:
balloon man
        selling pins
        for popping
text.426:
On the same bus
            the same strangers
                 as yesterday
text.427:
New neighbor
        eyeing the worn path
        between our houses
text.428:
a man swept by
            in a wave rising, falling
                 sees us see him drown
text.429:
fingering my tattoo
        granddaughter asks
        when she can have numbers
text.430:
the words unspoken . . .
        waiting for the toast
                to pop up
text.431:
drilling deeper
        my dentist talks me into
        Amnesty International
text.432:
Methodical husband:
        On his list of chores, she finds
        Her name
text.433:
running down
           FIGHT ILLITERACY
        the gang’s red paint
text.434:
drunken sailor
        loses both shoes
        tying one on
text.435:
eating alone
        my alphabet soup
        speaks to me
text.436:
lunch
        with her lover’s wife
        leftovers
text.437:
Hole in the ozone
        my bald spot . . .
        sunburned
text.438:
after kindling
        his passion . . .
        she lights his cigarette
text.439:
Nurse’s Station
        above the heart monitors
        a soap opera
text.440:
how desirable
        in the thrift shop window
        my old Mag Johng set
text.441:
hopscotch
        a one legged man
        raises cane
text.442:
young lawyer
        his briefs
        in the snow
text.443:
in his mother’s house
        he walks into the cobweb
        she underlooked
text.444:
Feel the warmth of
        Basho’s frogpond
        just xeroxed
text.445:
behind shadow proof blinds
        the calligrapher’s
        word processor
text.446:
spring rain—
              milk in her left breast
              unexpectedly sweeter
text.447:
spring evening
  the children's promise
  not to get cold
text.448:
jackknifed rig
              the trooper waves us
              into wildflowers
text.449:
the numbness
  of scar tissue
  forsythia
text.450:
autumn wind
  in his sweater pocket
  the missing button
text.451:
squash vines
              long and hollow
              the last late evenings
text.452:
dim light
  the night nurse
  describes the rain
text.453:
late summer
  black men spreading tar
  on the side road
text.454:
knowing your cough
              but not your face
              invalid neighbor
text.455:
spring plowing
  a flock of blackbirds
  turns inside out
text.456:
squash vines
  long and hollow
  the last late evenings
text.457:
dusk—
                up to my ears
                in birdsong
text.458:
all around
  light falling in a field
  of fireflies
text.459:
Independence Day
  I let him touch
  a little bit of me
text.460: snake hunting the boy sheds his shirt
text.461:
whistling
  he
  hangs
  the
  birdhouse
  he
  built
text.462:
summer evening
  fanning myself
  with a paper moon
text.463:
close lightning
   the metallic taste
            in my mouth
text.464:
garden work—
  talking to each other
  back to back
text.465:
dry heat—
  to the same withered flower
  a bee returns
text.466:
starry night—
                biting into a melon
                full of seeds
text.467:
I brush
  my mother’s hair
  the sparks
text.468:
snowflakes glued
  to the kindergarten window—
  no two alike
text.469:
undefended:
   in the cold rain
   their snow fort
text.470:
faint city stars …
  the moth’s copper dust
  in my palm
text.472:
porch swing
   now and then     a breeze
      from the river
text.473:
January thaw
  the narrow path
  fading away
text.474:
spring planting
                her refusal
                to compromise
text.475:
Logging road—
          the pileated woodpecker
                    flings its cry ahead
text.476:
ill again
  a dry leaf
  across porch boards
text.477:
leaving the park—
                glimpses of cherry petals
                on the soles of shoes
text.478:
Lily pond
   with one step the snowy egret
  moves the moon
text.479:
the white v of a killdeer’s wings
  opening in the wake
  of its cry
text.481:
a pile of rocks
                shifting in spring rain
                the stiff old man
text.482:
getting louder
  the calf
  the auctioneer
text.483:
bird shadow
  from tree shadow
  to fence shadow
text.484: i climb the mountain with my eyes never ending snow
text.485:
the petals scatter
                over graves swept
                and unswept
text.486:
a single leaf falling
   and with it
      the morning dew
text.487:
mountain rose—
  from thorn to thorn
  a spider’s line
text.488:
coming out of the woods—
  the sound of crickets,
  the empty sky
text.489:
An old woman with bread
                waves the geese down
                from the sky.
text.490:
over the earth’s edge
  they all go—the white clouds
  and the one sailboat
text.491:
long beards longer
                black clothes darker
                under july sun
text.492:
amish gentleman's
                warm smile brief . . .
                my skirt long and plain
text.493:
an amish grin
                as he cycles past
                the station selling gas
text.494:
the gloom within
                a handcrafts store . . .
                dolls with missing faces
text.495:
facing mirrors
                long-skirted woman
                and her amish child
text.496:
music on the wind
                an amish foot softly taps
                and abruptly stops
text.497:
late night camp . . .
                now a gentle lullaby
                horse hooves heading home
text.498:
falling leaves
                day by day
                the house grows brighter
text.499:
darkening path
  the white morning glories
         lead the way
text.500:
in a backyard
                two women folding sunlight
    into sheets
text.501:
late autumn
  the billboard's shadow leans
  into the woods
text.502:
from the stream
  two mallards fly straight up
  through falling leaves
text.503:
new year's eve blizzard—
  a neon beer-sign glows
  behind the steamed window
text.504:
spring breeze
  the woods road is still wet
  under the pines
text.505:
the old watering can
  hangs one more rainbow
  among the roses
text.506:
the evening paper
  on the darkening lawn—
  first star
text.507:
a letter stuck
  in the 11th floor mail chute—
  summer night
text.508:
the blues singer
  tells how bad it is
  then the sax tells you too
text.509:
quiet afternoon—
  in the meadow, one daisy
  leans on another
text.510:
at the end of a tunnel in the clouds
  a sunlit billow
text.511:
crossing the tracks
  at twilight—
  the autumn wind
text.512:
chilly sunrise
  a strip of bark flutters
  on the lake-side birch
text.513:
twiddling my thumbs
  the sun goes down,
  the moon comes up
text.514:
winter drizzle—
  unloading a crate of live ducks
  behind the chinatown restaurant
text.515:
snow melts by the hardware counter—
  the squares of color
  in the paint catalog
text.516:
in the mirrors on her dress
  little pieces of my
  self
text.517:
a few blocks
  from the street festival—
  the evening quiet
text.518:
at the pow-wow—
  they pass out ordinary saltines
  for the ceremony
text.520:
by the lawn's edge,
  the dog barks at the darkness
  then looks back at me
text.521:
dead end—
  a few leaves circle
  in the headlights
text.522:
late at night—
  a woman alone in the restaurant
  addressing christmas cards
text.523:
snowy morning
  the barber appears
  in his mirrors
text.525:
changing pitchers—
  the base-runner looks up
  at a passing cloud
text.526:
in the subway
  the young conductor cues
  imaginary oboes
text.527:
climbing the stairs
  more slowly—
  autumn evening
text.528:
the frozen puddle—
  kids slide over a pattern
  of red leaves
text.529:
snow drifts
  above the bear's den
  starry night
text.530:
cold spring rain—
  a piece of grass sticks out of the birdhouse
text.531:
Up in the sky
  hardly heard, hardly seen:
  migrating birds
text.532:
sundawn
                a flutter of mourning doves,
& poised, light-bathed, one faun
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.533:
mapletree buds,
                their small shadows
                in water-glazed mud
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.534:
white lilac
                fragrantly exuberant
                beside the porchdeck
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.535:
putting down a book
                to listen to the god
                in the half-cleared brook
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.536:
high noon
                straight-up trunks of poplars shadowless
                a foreshadowing ... soon, soon?
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.537:
watching a program
                on Brazil’s rain forests,
                anger poisons calm
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.538:
on the grass
                two pitched-from-a-car beer cans.
                unthinking ass!
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.539:
a cardinal's song
                blends with the brilliant sunset.
                surely, nothing's wrong?
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.540:
cicadas at dusk—
                seventeen years hence, shall we see
                substance or husk?
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.541:
in moonlight
                swish of owl wings, this heartstab:
                glitter can gloss blight
                                           nearby, a bell tolls changes
text.542:
First spring day
                melting and melting and melting
                tracks of the mountain man.
text.543:
night storm —
                a deeper dark unrolls
                across the prairie
text.544:
removing her wedding ring
  she brushes ¡t along
  her husband's name
text.545:
woman touches a name
  while looking at
  an old photo
text.546:
elderly couple
  their faces reflected
  over their son's name
text.547:
man in a filthy army jacket
  tries to scratch on
  his name
text.548:
anzio beach …
           another wave gathers
                and breaks
text.549: How many dew drops make up these walls?
text.550:
On razor wire 
  squats a crow—
  winter night
text.551:
The guards in their towers: 
  silk worms in cocoons of light
text.552:
Black-uniformed winter fly
  greeting me
  behind bullet-proof glass
text.553:
Walls of ice 
      deep in forests
            frozen frogponds
text.554:
My silver shackles—
  gossamer threads 
  under these stars
text.555:
Old guard escorting me
       coughing like bullfrog
             cigarette smoke for breath
text.556:
Prison cat in shadows
  stalking the shaft of searchlight
text.557: Capturing snowflake fireflies with my tongue
text.558:
Beating time with nightstick,
  cricket sound
  while I urinate
text.559:
Oh, winter moon,
  what have you done now
  keep-locked with the mountains?
text.560:
A thousand temple bells—
  the noise of the cell block
text.561: Suddenly they all look like green bullfrogs!
text.562:
Decorating my cell again
     I notice roommate—
         a silverfish on my pillow
text.563:
From out of Henderson’s Haiku,
     my old wife’s photograph:
           cells doors automatically locking.
text.564:
soothing rain:
  the mown meadow releases
  pungence of mint
text.565:
Butterfly shadows …
     not finding
          the butterfly
text.566:
abandoned farmhouse: 
  bird nest in the mail box 
  also deserted
text.567:
abandoned farmhouse: 
  wallpaper peeling back to 
  my childhood
text.568:
abandoned farmhouse: 
  something scratching 
  inside the furnace
text.569:
abandoned farmhouse: 
  the quiet bedroom where I 
  feared the dark
text.570:
abandoned farmhouse: a 
  yellowed grocery list taped 
  to the counter top
text.571:
abandoned farmhouse: a 
  moth flies out of the water 
  faucet
text.572:
abandoned farmhouse:
  my daughter
  snaps pictures of our visit
text.573:
Into old pots and pans
  thrown out in the backyard—
  the musical rain
text.574:
here & there 
  in bare treetops 
  mistletoe
text.575:
in a shabby motel 
  all night 
  treefrogs in rain
text.576:
cottonmouths 
  in the swamp ... 
  a house on stilts
text.578:
family get-together 
  all the eyes all the feelers 
  all the hands tearing shrimp
text.579:
morning in the French Quarter 
  café au lait & 
  beignets      with sparrows
text.580:
the river wind blows 
  into the Quarter 
& through his saxophone
text.581:
on the riverfront
  a stranger
  takes my smile
text.582:
the breeze
  off the Mississippi
  fills my skirt
text.583:
behind grillwork
  down darkness to sun
  in a hidden courtyard
text.584:
cool the alley
  through the grillwork swirls
  cat pee smell
text.585:
in the morning shops
  half the doorways
  fill with shade
text.586:
all the Mardi Gras colors
  in the masks
  in the houses
text.587:
on the iron lace balconies
  only flowers
  sunning
text.588:
from the suite dusk
  fills in the river
& all the tiny lights are slow
text.590:
huge limbs of the live oak
  their reaching out
  over the young grass
text.591:
in a pecan grove
  wandering spring shadows
     cows & blackbirds
text.592:
parked on the runway
  its wings drooped     a B-52
  the winter sun
text.593:
the slow day ...
  in the empty motel corridor
  a stack of dirty dishes
text.594:
sundown in the empty bar
  the player-piano keys
  begin
text.595:
the big waitress departs
  the china teapot
  shakes
text.596:
January sun ...
  the cotton fields
  dotted with leftovers
text.597:
longest night—
                his forehead burning
                into my hand
text.598:
what passion
  you had, Akiko—
  where can I put
  even an inch
  of tonight's anguish!
text.599:
sucking
  chocolate squares—
  oh, it's a lonely beginning
  this first night of return
  to Japan
text.600:
under this Basholess
  pre-dawn sky
  how rough
  the angle of loneliness
  along this eastern sea
text.601:
bent
  like a puzzle
  in a child's hand,
  that back before me
  in the pre-dawn dark
text.602:
is it a walking
  umbrella?
  immense the black
  over that bent-against-the-wind
  angle of loneliness
text.603:
a crane
  skipping before me
  on this seaside road,
  its leg
  a karate lift?
text.604:
I hug
  the boy to me—
  how brave he was to point and say
  This is a pencil
  This is a cup
text.605:
on my office couch
  I lean back,
  back,
  this Nescafe's
  the length of my desire
text.606:
in this bare
  late-afternoon life
  I make
  my bare dinner
  and set out fork and knife
text.607:
wanting
  to embrace
  even a sleeve—
  tonight's
  lonely angle
text.608:
gone from the wood
      the bird I knew
           by song alone
text.609:
on Lookout Rock
  one step
  to the red hawk
text.610:
I
  A red shaft of light
  dances on your moist eyelids:
  the searing morning.
text.611:
II
  Frog Mountain rises
  to arch its back in the clouds:
  unforeseen downpour.
text.612:
III
  Three men and three birds
  stand still in the forest, all
  surprised by rain.
text.613:
IV
  Rain like the Deluge:
  a mudspattered Apache
  sings in Cibecue.
text.614:
V
  The day hides itself
  within a grove of aspen.
  Thunder pursues it.
text.615:
VI
  Uprooted clouds:
  Summer holds the pale mountains,
  calls down the clear night.
text.616:
cajun cabin …
  the aroma of hot gumbo
  floats on the bayou
text.617:
Gunshot! 
  The tide of gulls breaks 
  like a scattering wave
text.618:
Gathering silence 
  in my mind is 
  the hardest thing to do
text.619:
Against the wind's chill 
  I button my sweater 
  feet dug in sand
text.620:
The sun slips low 
  a carnelian red paving 
  the water with dark light
text.621:
How many wanderers 
  have followed the sun 
  down?
text.622:
(The girl with the soul 
  of a gull 
  never came back)
text.623:
Questions 
  purl like schools of fish 
  in dangerous waters
text.624:
Questions 
  without breath without answers 
  a broken shell
text.625:
on the cardboard box
    holding the frozen wino:
        Fragile: Do Not Crush
text.626:
From the fire escape
    the cry of the mourning dove
          wintering over
text.627:
New condominium
    its exhaust grate claimed by
         a new derelict
text.628:
Wind chill minus five
     the piercing whistles
           of the starlings
text.629:
The young mother
     stoops to warm the child's mittens
           between her gloves
text.630:
Between lace curtains
     the white cat's eyes
          follow a snowflake
text.631:
A crow flies down
     to land in the new snow
          its voice ringing
text.632:
Madison Avenue
     a row of ginkgoes mulched
          with old Xmas trees
text.633:
Suet on a string
      suspended from a snowy branch
            three sparrows make it spin
text.634:
In the shadow of
    office buildings, bagpiper's
         Amazing Grace
text.635:
Last night’s fading dream …
  On the blue teapot birds drift
  beyond the willows
text.637:
April sun slanting
  across the exercise yard
      jail-bar shadows
text.638:
Basketball stops
     in the exercise yard—
  convicts shoot the breeze
text.639:
This heat!
  snow-clad mountains framed
      by my jail cell window
text.640:
Little ladybug
  caught after visiting hours:
    doing jail time, too
text.642:
Chilly June morning—
    in a spider web
  the jailhouse fly hangs
text.643:
Sixty day jail term—
  as it grows shorter
  my growing beard
text.644:
a swallowtail
                 settles
  on the prize-winning quilt
text.645:
summer afternoon—
  the priest takes a blue pencil
  from the blind man
text.646:
coming up through
  a gap in the city bridge. .
  a checkerspot butterfly
text.647:
backfire—
  a checkerspot in its sound
  shifts direction
text.648:
dog coming out
  with the cathedral crowd. .
  tail upward
text.649:
half way home
  pole shadows reach across
  the widening road
text.650:
train whistle—
  two jets wrap the sky
  with mist
text.651:
a block from home
  a pair of rain drops find
  my haiku notes
text.652:
snow geese
  Sarah discovers
  the letter V
text.653:
suddenly—
  twenty years later
  you taste the same
text.654:
through two marriages
  framed behind Beethoven
  your picture
text.655:
talking with him
  I taste you
  in the tea you serve
text.656:
on your porch
  only the breeze
  moves between us
text.657:
in the dark car
  the scent of you
  and the rainy fields
text.658:
juice from the apple
  runs into my beard
  as I wait for you
text.659:
in the mirror
  the only picture
  of us together
text.660:
your perfume—
  looking up startled
  at a stranger
text.661:
in the cold fireplace
  my last letter
  burning
text.662:
still in the taste
                of afternoon tea,
                my grandmother’s brogue
text.663:
a horse-drawn plow:
  sunflowers stand
  in the traces
text.664:
Eaves
           pulling sound
                                   from the wind
text.665:
walking alone
  the way oak leaves
     refuse to fall
text.666:
a steady rain
                the dentist’s drill
                turning to snow
text.667:
top of the falls
     your voice somewhere
  in its sound
text.668:
The worm
  far out on this paved lot
  more rain
text.669: autumn dusk the crooked road home
text.670:
winter morning—
                  the closet dark with
                  old shoes
text.671:
The family gathered—
  a tear of embalming fluid runs
  from my brother’s eye
text.672:
a moth flies
  through my breath
  in moonlight
text.673:
bitter wind …
  the hand that cups the flame
  aglow
text.674:
The sound of scissors
              through quilt stuffing:
     chill autumn moon
text.675:
autumn maple
              a gust of yellow scatters
              the child’s laughter
text.676:
autumn sky
              the wind folds and unfolds
              a flock of sparrows
text.677:
moving into the sun
              the pony takes with him
              some mountain shadow
text.678:
paddling slowly
 through the reeds
              that touch her hair
text.679:
the old woman
              looking into the stars
     sky all snowy
text.680:
Against his coat
              I brush my lips—
              the silence of snowflakes
text.681:
away from eyes
              the stairwell holds
              us in its arms
text.682:
that sonofabitch
              on the corner has a knife—
              the rain glistens on it
text.684:
Winter’s end
   a bitterness remaining
        in the dried apricots
text.685:
the old garden fence
              now keeps the goldenrod
              from the goldenrod
text.686:
Thin icicles
              on the telephone wire
              her distant voice
text.687:
hoping the shape
              of the navel will be good
              father cuts the cord
text.688: one cricket       sound and silence lighting the autumn garden
text.689:
hot rock by the stream
              each of the baby’s toeprints
              evaporating
text.690:
switching off the light
              switching off the shadows
